Practical tips when working 100% remote: At the end of the work day, shut down your corporate-issued PC. The startup time is a good deterrent to not slip into doing sporadic work during off-hours.

5 tips for nailing your startup pitch:
1. Understand why your product is unique
2. Know everything about your product
3. Know each of your competitors
4. Know your numbers (MRR, Growth Rate, Sales, Margins)
5. Prep and practice until it's natural

Define and follow standards is the only universal "tip" I can give to startups.

Programmers: Pick one and follow it. E.g "The microsoft C# standard". Enforce with an automatic code linter (.EditorConfig)
Audio/Art: Define and follow a file naming standard.

#Business #Tip : As a startup, it’s generally better to start with a small office space and grow out of it than with a large one with lots of empty space for a while. Not only is it better for your cash flow, but also a busy crowded office is an indication of a growing company.

Tip to college students confused between academia / startups : 

If you like going slow and playing within the rules, pick academia. 

If you like bending rules and negotiating with the world, pick startups.

#Pitchdeck tips:
The summary slide has the purpose of making investors curious about your business. It’s time to reveal the essence of your startup & this reveal has to be well planned. First, you explain what your business does in less than 30 words & they have to be on point.

#Pitchdeck tips:
The title slide of your pitch deck provides the first impression of your Startup to your potential Investor.

Statistics say that you only have about 7 seconds for this first impression. Therefore, the title slides must be eye-catching and memorable.

my 5 tips to build a product vision:
1) understand your customer, find the want 
2) industry + market data  
3) build your MVP, understand technical constraints 
4) prepare to take risks, learn from feedback 
5) effectively communicate the vision
